questions.prompt: The convex hull of a set of points in the plane is:
options: The smallest convex polygon containing all points
questions.correctAnswer: The smallest convex polygon containing all points
questions.explanation: The convex hull is the minimal convex set containing the points; in 2D it is a convex polygon whose vertices are a subset of the points.

questions.prompt: Graham scan runs in O(n _____) time due to sorting by angle.
questions.explanation: Graham scan sorts points (O(n log n)) and then does a linear scan, so the total time is O(n log n).

questions.prompt: Orientation tests in computational geometry can be computed using a 2D cross product (signed area).
questions.explanation: The sign of the cross product (b−a)×(c−a) indicates clockwise vs counterclockwise turn, central to convex hull and segment intersection algorithms.

questions.prompt: A sweep line algorithm is characterized by:
options: Processing events in sorted order while maintaining an active set
Using max flow as a subroutine
questions.correctAnswer: Processing events in sorted order while maintaining an active set
questions.explanation: Sweep line methods sort “events” (like segment endpoints) and maintain a data structure of active objects intersecting the sweep line.
The cross product is 1*1 − 0*1 = 1, positive, indicating a counterclockwise turn; Math.sign prints 1.

questions.prompt: The divide-and-conquer closest pair of points algorithm runs in:
questions.explanation: Closest pair can be solved in O(n log n) by sorting once and using a divide-and-conquer merge step that checks a constant number of neighbors in the strip.

questions.prompt: Line segment intersection can be solved in O(n log n) time for n segments using a sweep line algorithm.
questions.explanation: Bentley–Ottmann finds all intersections in O((n+k) log n), and detecting whether any intersection exists can be done in O(n log n).

questions.prompt: Voronoi diagrams are dual to the _____ triangulation.
questions.explanation: The Delaunay triangulation is the geometric dual of the Voronoi diagram: edges connect sites with adjacent Voronoi cells.

questions.prompt: A common data structure for 2D orthogonal range searching is a:
questions.explanation: Range trees (and kd-trees) are standard structures for orthogonal range searching, enabling sublinear query times with preprocessing.

questions.prompt: Polygon triangulation is often used to:
options: Decompose a polygon into triangles for rendering or dynamic programming
questions.correctAnswer: Decompose a polygon into triangles for rendering or dynamic programming
questions.explanation: Triangulation breaks a polygon into triangles, useful in graphics and as a basis for DP solutions on polygons.

questions.prompt: Robust computational geometry implementations must often address:
options: That all inputs are in general position
questions.explanation: Geometric predicates are sensitive to numeric error and degenerate cases. Robust implementations use exact arithmetic, epsilons carefully, or symbolic perturbation.

questions.prompt: In the plane, computing a convex hull can be done in expected O(n) time using randomized incremental construction.
questions.explanation: There are randomized incremental algorithms with expected linear time under certain models, though the most common deterministic algorithms are O(n log n).

questions.prompt: A standard approach to avoid many floating-point issues in orientation is to use exact _____ arithmetic when feasible.
questions.explanation: If coordinates are integers and within safe range, computing cross products with integer arithmetic avoids rounding error (though overflow must still be managed).

questions.prompt: The output-sensitive convex hull algorithm Jarvis March runs in:
questions.explanation: Jarvis March (gift wrapping) takes O(nh) time where h is the number of hull vertices, making it fast when the hull is small.

questions.prompt: Which statement about computational geometry algorithms is generally true?
options: Many algorithms rely on sorting events/points and geometric predicates like orientation
Most problems reduce to max flow
Precision issues never arise in practice
All problems have linear-time deterministic solutions
questions.correctAnswer: Many algorithms rely on sorting events/points and geometric predicates like orientation
questions.explanation: A large fraction of planar computational geometry uses sorting and a small set of geometric predicates (orientation, in-circle), combined with sweeps or divide-and-conquer.
